The Related Discourses

6. Deathlessness

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

There was a monk named Ariṣṭa who went to the Buddha, prostrated at his feet, and withdrew to sit at one side. He said, “Bhagavān, there’s what’s called ‘deathless.’2 What is called ‘deathless’?”

Buddha addressed Ariṣṭa, “‘Deathless’ is an element named as a description, but I take it to be the possession of the end of contaminants. It’s a clear explanation of this name.”

The monk Ariṣṭa said to the Buddha, “Bhagavān, isn’t there a path and steps to attain deathlessness when they are cultivated and cultivated often?”

The Buddha addressed the monk, “There is. It’s known as the noble eightfold path, which is right view up to right concentration.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. The Pali parallel is SN.45.7 Dutiyaaññatarabhikkhu. The Pali sutta is only partially parallel, containing a question about the “deathless” and equating it with the end of the contaminants.
  2. The Chinese translates amṛta as ‘sweet dew’ 甘露, which was a mythical substance considered to be parallel to the Indian concept of soma that was the food of the gods.
Translator: Charles Patton
